code: model <- multimedia(exper, glmnet_model(lambda = 0.1)) |>     estimate(exper) direct <- list(     CD = direct_effect(model, exper),     UC = direct_effect(model, exper, 3, 2) ) |>     map_dfr(effect_summary, .id = "treatment")  vis_direct <- direct |>     slice_max(abs(direct_effect), n = 20) |>     pull(outcome)  combined |>     select(any_of(vis_direct), Study.Group) |>     pivot_longer(-Study.Group, names_to = "feature") |>     ggplot() +     geom_boxplot(         aes(value, reorder(feature, value, median),             fill = Study.Group         )     ) +     labs(         x = "log(1 + intensity)",         y = "Metabolite",         fill = "Group"     ) indirect_effect <- list(     CD = indirect_overall(model, exper),     UC = indirect_overall(model, exper, 3, 2) )  top_direct <- dplyr::rename(direct, effect = direct_effect) top_indirect <- dplyr::rename(bind_rows(indirect_effect),     effect = indirect_effect ) top_effects <- list(direct = top_direct, indirect = top_indirect) |>     bind_rows(.id = "type")  vis_outcomes <- c(     "m0181_hydrocinnamic_acid", "m1303_lithocholate",     "m0036_creatinine", "m0253_sphingosine", "m1478_C182_CE",     "m0295_arginine" ) top_effects <- bind_rows(     filter(top_effects, outcome %in% vis_outcomes[1:3], type == "indirect"),     filter(top_effects, outcome %in% vis_outcomes[4:6], type == "direct"), ) eig <- \(x, k) 100 * round(x[k] / sum(x), 4)  mds <- cmdscale(dist(mediators(exper)), eig = TRUE, k = 2) coords <- data.frame(mds$points) |>     bind_cols(treatments(exper)) |>     bind_cols(outcomes(exper)[, vis_outcomes]) |>     pivot_longer(top_effects$outcome,         names_to = "outcome",         values_to = "abundance"     ) |>     left_join(top_effects) |>     group_by(outcome) |>     mutate(abundance_quantile = as.integer(as.factor(cut(abundance, 10))) / 10)  ggplot(coords) +     geom_point(aes(X1, X2, col = Study.Group, size = abundance_quantile)) +     scale_size_area(max_size = 1.5, breaks = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75)) +     labs(         x = glue("MDS1 [{eig(mds$eig, 1)}%]"),         y = glue("MDS2 [{eig(mds$eig, 2)}%]"),         size = "Metabolite Abundance Quantile",         col = "Group"     ) +     facet_wrap(~ type + reorder(outcome, -abundance)) confound_ix <- data.frame(     outcome = vis_outcomes,     mediator = "gEnterocloster" ) rho_seq <- seq(-0.5, 0.5, length.out = 10) # sensitivity_overall <- sensitivity( #     model, exper, confound_ix, n_boot = 100, rho_seq = rho_seq, t1 = 1, t2 = 2 # ) sensitivity_overall <- read_csv("https://go.wisc.edu/aj4vg9") sensitivity_overall |>     filter(outcome %in% vis_outcomes) |>     ggplot(aes(rho, indirect_effect)) +     geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +     geom_ribbon(         aes(             ymin = indirect_effect - 2 * indirect_effect_standard_error,              ymax = indirect_effect + 2 * indirect_effect_standard_error         ),         alpha = 0.2, linewidth = 1     ) +     scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +     facet_wrap(~ reorder(outcome, indirect_effect)) +     geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linetype = 3, linewidth = 1) +     labs(         x = expression("Confounder Correlation Strength" ~ rho),         y = "Estimated Overall Indirect Effect"     ) # indirect_sorted <- list( #     CD = indirect_pathwise(model, exper), #     UC = indirect_pathwise(model, exper, 3, 2) # ) |> #     map_dfr(effect_summary, .id = "treatment") indirect_sorted <- read_csv("https://go.wisc.edu/0c6qkt") p <- indirect_sorted %>%     split(.$treatment) |>     map(~ arrange(., -indirect_effect) |>         plot_mediators(exper, treatment = "Study.Group", nrow = 2))  p[["CD"]] altered <- model |>     nullify("T->Y") |>     estimate(exper)  # sample at original treatment assignments profile <- setup_profile(model, treatments(exper), treatments(exper)) samples <- list(     real = outcomes(exper),     fitted = outcomes(sample(model, profile = profile)),     altered = outcomes(sample(altered, profile = profile)) ) |>     bind_rows(.id = "source") |>     bind_cols(treatment = rep(treatments(exper)$Study.Group, 3)) |>     pivot_longer(direct$outcome) |>     mutate(name = factor(name, levels = unique(direct$outcome)))  # visualize ggplot(filter(samples, samples$name %in% unique(samples$name)[1:20])) +     geom_boxplot(aes(value, name, fill = treatment)) +     facet_wrap(~source) fs <- list(direct = direct_effect, indirect = indirect_overall) # inference <- bootstrap(model, exper, fs, B = 1000) inference <- readRDS(url("https://go.wisc.edu/08o4l0")) filter_outcomes <- inference$indirect |>     effect_summary() |>     group_by(outcome) |>     summarise(indirect_effect = median(indirect_effect)) |>     slice_max(abs(indirect_effect), n = 20) |>     pull(outcome)  p1 <- filter(inference$indirect, outcome %in% filter_outcomes) |>     ggplot() +     geom_vline(xintercept = 0) +     stat_slabinterval(         aes(indirect_effect, reorder(outcome, indirect_effect, median)),         .width = c(.66, .95)     ) +     labs(x = "Indirect Effect", y = "Metabolite")  filter_outcomes <- inference$direct |>     group_by(outcome) |>     summarise(direct_effect = median(direct_effect)) |>     slice_max(abs(direct_effect), n = 20) |>     pull(outcome) p2 <- filter(inference$direct, outcome %in% filter_outcomes) |>     ggplot() +     geom_vline(xintercept = 0) +     stat_slabinterval(         aes(direct_effect, reorder(outcome, direct_effect, median)),         .width = c(.66, .95)     ) +     labs(x = "Direct Effect", y = "Metabolite")  p1 | p2 confound_ix <- data.frame(     mediator = c("gCholadousia", "gBilophila", "gCAG103"),     outcome = c(         "m0066_taurine", "m0066_taurine", "m0900_ketodeoxycholate"     ) )  #sensitivity_path <- sensitivity_pathwise(model, exper, confound_ix, rho_seq, 1) sensitivity_path <- read_csv("https://go.wisc.edu/ph7ek4") confound_ix |>     left_join(sensitivity_path) |>     ggplot(aes(rho, indirect_effect, group = contrast)) +     geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linetype = 3, linewidth = 1) +     geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = 3, linewidth = 1) +     geom_line(linewidth = 2) +     labs(         x = expression("Confounding parameter"~ rho),         y = "Estimated Indirect Effect"     ) +     theme(         axis.title = element_text(size = 16),         strip.text = element_text(size = 14)     ) +     facet_wrap(         reorder(outcome, indirect_effect) ~ reorder(mediator, indirect_effect),         scales = "free_y"     )

title: The Mindfulness Study
text: LNM makes relatively strong assumptions outcome model: effects must enter linearly multinomial likelihood. nonparametric alternative, can fit separate random forest models microbe’s abundance. Since model doesn’t directly account compositions, help transform response relative abundances. can compute direct indirect effects estimated model. can visualize features largest direct indirect effects. Nonlinearity seems helped uncover mediator microbe relationships, example, relationships sleep disturbance/Ruminococcus2 cereal/Faecalibacterium.
code: model <- multimedia(     exper_rela,     rf_model(num.trees = 50),     glmnet_model(lambda = 0.5, alpha = 0) ) |>     estimate(exper_rela) direct <- direct_effect(model, exper_rela) direct_sorted <- direct |>     group_by(outcome, contrast) |>     summarise(direct_effect = mean(direct_effect)) |>     arrange(-direct_effect)  indirect_sorted <- indirect_pathwise(model, exper_rela) |>     group_by(outcome, mediator, contrast) |>     summarise(indirect_effect = mean(indirect_effect)) |>     arrange(-abs(indirect_effect))  direct_sorted #> # A tibble: 55 × 3 #> # Groups:   outcome [55] #>    outcome               contrast            direct_effect #>                                             #>  1 Ruminococcus          Control - Treatment      0.00476  #>  2 Faecalibacterium      Control - Treatment      0.00309  #>  3 Coprococcus           Control - Treatment      0.00251  #>  4 Roseburia             Control - Treatment      0.00243  #>  5 Gemmiger              Control - Treatment      0.00109  #>  6 Parabacteroides       Control - Treatment      0.00108  #>  7 Dorea                 Control - Treatment      0.000857 #>  8 Streptococcus         Control - Treatment      0.000842 #>  9 Bacteroides           Control - Treatment      0.000295 #> 10 Phascolarctobacterium Control - Treatment      0.000210 #> # ℹ 45 more rows indirect_sorted #> # A tibble: 220 × 4 #> # Groups:   outcome, mediator [220] #>    outcome          mediator                    contrast         indirect_effect #>                                                              #>  1 Ruminococcus     mediator.Cold.cereal        Control - Treat…        -0.0104  #>  2 Blautia          mediator.sleepDistRaw       Control - Treat…         0.00762 #>  3 Blautia          mediator.Cold.cereal        Control - Treat…         0.00670 #>  4 Clostridium_IV   mediator.Cold.cereal        Control - Treat…        -0.00627 #>  5 Prevotella       mediator.Fruit..not.juices. title: The Mindfulness Study
text: bootstrap can help evaluate uncertainty complex statistics, ’s good option random forest analysis. iteration, randomly subsample timepoints original experiment compute list estimates, specified list funs . output concatenates output across bootstrap iterations. can now visualize bootstrap confidence intervals associated estimated effects. largest interval corresponds 90% bootstrap confidence interval. inner interval covers median +/- one-third bootstrap distribution’s mass. associations certainly seem worth following , though data needed validation. Notice direct effects seem generally stronger indirect effects. Even flexible random forest model, seems changes diet sleep alone enough explain changes microbiome composition seen study. suggests mechanisms related gut-brain axis may play, lying behind observed direct effects.
code: funs <- list(direct = direct_effect, indirect = indirect_overall) # inference <- bootstrap(model, exper_rela, funs, B = 1e3) inference <- readRDS(url("https://go.wisc.edu/ba3e87")) p1 <- ggplot(inference$indirect) +     geom_vline(xintercept = 0) +     stat_slabinterval(         aes(indirect_effect, reorder(outcome, indirect_effect, median)),         .width = c(.66, .95)     ) +     labs(         title = "Indirect Effects", y = "Taxon", x = "Effect (Rel. title: Multimodal Mediation Analysis
text: multimedia R package multimodal mediation analysis microbiome data. streamlines data curation, mediation outcome model specification, statistical inference direct indirect effects. defining causal relationships across data modalities, can support principled data integration. can read package preprint: H. Jiang, X. Miao, M. W. Thairu, M. Beebe, D. W. Grupe, R. J. Davidson, J. Handelsman, K. Sankaran (2024). multimedia: Multimodal Mediation Analysis Microbiome Data. preprint describes scientific context interpretation two vignettes package. One gives multi-omics analysis IBD, describes simultaneously model 16S profiles survey responses mindfulness intervention study.

title: Multimodal Mediation Analysis
text: can install development version GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("krisrs1128/multimedia")

title: Multimodal Mediation Analysis
text: simple example estimating direct indirect effects. data randomly generated (real effects), imagine ASV columns mediate relationship treatment PHQ. mimics possibility microbiome (ASV = Amplicon Sequence Variant) mediates relationship treatment depression (PHQ = Patient Health Questionnaire). can find details random.Rmd vignette. original data SummarizedExperiment. package can also take phyloseq objects data.frames. Next, specify columns treatment, mediators, outcomes. Notice can use tidyselect syntax match multiple columns. Next, fit mediation analysis components estimate effects. default, package uses linear models – see vignettes examples using sparse regression, random forests, bayesian hierarchical models instead. mediation analysis, several types effects interesting, corresponding different ways traveling treatment outcome mediation analysis causal graph. block , direct_effect captures treatment effects bypass microbiome; indirect_effect effects mediated ASV relative abundances. Since example uses linear model, effects identical two indirect settings. package also includes helpers visualize perform inference effects. example,  want use different type model, can just modify original multimedia specification. use sparse regression model, correctly recovers direct effects 0.
code: library(multimedia)  ## Loading required package: brms  ## Loading required package: Rcpp  ## Loading 'brms' package (version 2.21.0). Useful instructions ## can be found by typing help('brms'). A more detailed introduction ## to the package is available through vignette('brms_overview').  ##  ## Attaching package: 'brms'  ## The following object is masked from 'package:stats': ##  ##     ar  ## Loading required package: glmnetUtils  ## Loading required package: ranger  ## Loading required package: tidyselect  demo_joy() ## class: SummarizedExperiment ## dim: 5 100 ## metadata(0): ## assays(1): counts ## rownames(5): ASV1 ASV2 ASV3 ASV4 ASV5 ## rowData names(0): ## colnames: NULL ## colData names(2): treatment PHQ exper <- mediation_data(demo_joy(), "PHQ", "treatment", starts_with("ASV")) exper ## [Mediation Data] ## 100 samples with measurements for, ## 1 treatment: treatment ## 5 mediators: ASV1, ASV2, ... ## 1 outcome: PHQ model <- multimedia(exper) |>     estimate(exper) model ## [Multimedia Analysis] ## Treatments: treatment ## Outcomes: PHQ ## Mediators: ASV1, ASV2, ... ## ## [Models] ## mediation: A fitted lm_model(). ## outcome: A fitted lm_model(). direct_effect(model, exper) ##   outcome indirect_setting            contrast direct_effect ## 1     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment    0.09314376 ## 2     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment    0.09314376 indirect_overall(model, exper) ##   outcome direct_setting            contrast indirect_effect ## 1     PHQ        Control Control - Treatment      0.02256029 ## 2     PHQ      Treatment Control - Treatment      0.02256029 boot <- bootstrap(model, exper, c(direct = direct_effect))  library(ggplot2) ggplot(boot$direct) +     geom_histogram(aes(direct_effect), bins = 20) +     scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +     theme_classic() +     labs(x = "Direct Effect", y = "Frequency", title = "Bootstrap Distribution") multimedia(exper, glmnet_model(lambda = .1)) |>     estimate(exper) |>     direct_effect() ##   outcome indirect_setting            contrast direct_effect ## 1     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment             0 ## 2     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment             0

title: Bootstrap Distribution for Estimators — bootstrap
text: model object class multimedia specified mediation outcome models want re-estimate across B bootstrap samples. exper object class multimedia_data containing mediation outcome data direct effects estimated. fs estimators whose bootstrap samples interested . assumed vector functions (example, direct_effect indirect_effect), applied bootstrap resample. B number bootstrap samples. Defaults 1000. progress logical indicating whether show progress bar.

title: Bootstrap Distribution for Estimators — bootstrap
text: stats list length B containing results fs applied B bootstrap resamples.

title: Bootstrap Distribution for Estimators — bootstrap
code: # example with null data. We set B to 5 just to execute quickly -- it's not # actually a practical choice of B exper <- demo_joy() |>     mediation_data("PHQ", "treatment", starts_with("ASV")) multimedia(exper) |>     bootstrap(exper, B = 5) #> Bootstrapping direct_effect #> $direct_effect #>    bootstrap outcome indirect_setting            contrast direct_effect #> 1          1     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment    -0.2157883 #> 2          1     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment    -0.2157883 #> 3          2     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment    -0.4556939 #> 4          2     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment    -0.4556939 #> 5          3     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment    -0.4300947 #> 6          3     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment    -0.4300947 #> 7          4     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment    -0.9455150 #> 8          4     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment    -0.9455150 #> 9          5     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment    -0.4629558 #> 10         5     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment    -0.4629558 #>   # example with another dataset exper <- demo_spline(n_samples = 100, tau = c(2, 1)) |>     mediation_data(starts_with("outcome"), "treatment", "mediator") samples <- multimedia(exper, rf_model(num.trees = 1e3)) |>     bootstrap(exper, B = 5) #> Bootstrapping direct_effect ggplot2::ggplot(samples$direct_effect) +     ggplot2::geom_histogram(         ggplot2::aes(direct_effect, fill = indirect_setting),         bins = 15     ) +     ggplot2::facet_wrap(~outcome, scales = "free")

title: Calibration using Synthetic Nulls — fdr_summary
text: contrast data.frame summarizing differences outcomes across hypothetical treatments, typically output null_contrast. row one outcome one hypothetical scenario. effect Either "indirect_overall" (default), "indirect_pathwise", "direct_effect" specifying type effect want select. q_value target false discovery rate control. last time estimated FDR threshold smallest magnitude effect size consider.

title: Calibration using Synthetic Nulls — fdr_summary
text: fdr data.frame specifying, candidate effect, whether selected.

title: Calibration using Synthetic Nulls — fdr_summary
code: # example with null data - notice synthetic data has larger effect. exper <- demo_joy() |>     mediation_data("PHQ", "treatment", starts_with("ASV")) multimedia(exper) |>     estimate(exper) |>     null_contrast(exper) |>     fdr_summary("direct_effect") #> Fitting the nullified model... #> Generating synthetic data... #> Fitting the full model on synthetic data... #> Estimating effects on real and synthetic data... #> # A tibble: 2 × 6 #>   source    outcome direct_effect  rank fdr_hat keep  #>   <chr>     <chr>           <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <lgl> #> 1 real      PHQ          -0.644       1     0   FALSE #> 2 synthetic PHQ          -0.00261     2     0.5 FALSE  multimedia(exper) |>     estimate(exper) |>     null_contrast(exper, "M->Y", indirect_overall) |>     fdr_summary("indirect_overall") #> Fitting the nullified model... #> Generating synthetic data... #> Fitting the full model on synthetic data... #> Estimating effects on real and synthetic data... #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `summarise()`. #> ℹ In argument: `ix = max(.data$rank)`. #> Caused by warning in `max()`: #> ! no non-missing arguments to max; returning -Inf #> # A tibble: 2 × 7 #>   source    outcome indirect_effect .group     rank fdr_hat keep  #>   <chr>     <chr>             <dbl> <chr>     <int>   <dbl> <lgl> #> 1 synthetic PHQ              0.0958 drop_last     1     1   FALSE #> 2 real      PHQ             -0.0310 drop_last     2     0.5 FALSE  # example with another dataset - synthetic effect is smaller. exper <- demo_spline(tau = c(2, 1)) |>     mediation_data(starts_with("outcome"), "treatment", "mediator") multimedia(exper) |>     estimate(exper) |>     null_contrast(exper) |>     fdr_summary("direct_effect") #> Fitting the nullified model... #> Generating synthetic data... #> Fitting the full model on synthetic data... #> Estimating effects on real and synthetic data... #> # A tibble: 4 × 6 #>   source    outcome   direct_effect  rank fdr_hat keep  #>   <chr>     <chr>             <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <lgl> #> 1 real      outcome_1      -1.85        1   0     TRUE  #> 2 real      outcome_2      -0.922       2   0     FALSE #> 3 synthetic outcome_2       0.0428      3   0.333 FALSE #> 4 synthetic outcome_1      -0.00474     4   0.5   FALSE  multimedia(exper) |>     estimate(exper) |>     null_contrast(exper, "M->Y", indirect_overall) |>     fdr_summary("indirect_overall") #> Fitting the nullified model... #> Generating synthetic data... #> Fitting the full model on synthetic data... #> Estimating effects on real and synthetic data... #> # A tibble: 4 × 7 #>   source    outcome   indirect_effect .group     rank fdr_hat keep  #>   <chr>     <chr>               <dbl> <chr>     <int>   <dbl> <lgl> #> 1 real      outcome_1          1.01   drop_last     1   0     TRUE  #> 2 real      outcome_2          0.512  drop_last     2   0     FALSE #> 3 synthetic outcome_2         -0.0246 drop_last     3   0.333 FALSE #> 4 synthetic outcome_1         -0.0176 drop_last     4   0.5   FALSE

code: # example with null data - notice synthetic data has larger effect. exper <- demo_joy() |>     mediation_data("PHQ", "treatment", starts_with("ASV")) multimedia(exper) |>     estimate(exper) |>     null_contrast(exper) #> Fitting the nullified model... #> Generating synthetic data... #> Fitting the full model on synthetic data... #> Estimating effects on real and synthetic data... #>      source outcome indirect_setting            contrast direct_effect #> 1      real     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment  -0.071142843 #> 2      real     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment  -0.071142843 #> 3 synthetic     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment   0.005206336 #> 4 synthetic     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment   0.005206336  # example with another dataset - synthetic effect is smaller. exper <- demo_spline(tau = c(2, 1)) |>     mediation_data(starts_with("outcome"), "treatment", "mediator") multimedia(exper) |>     estimate(exper) |>     null_contrast(exper) #> Fitting the nullified model... #> Generating synthetic data... #> Fitting the full model on synthetic data... #> Estimating effects on real and synthetic data... #>      source   outcome indirect_setting contrast direct_effect #> 1      real outcome_1                0    0 - 1   -2.14038433 #> 2      real outcome_2                0    0 - 1   -0.90576806 #> 3      real outcome_1                1    0 - 1   -2.14038433 #> 4      real outcome_2                1    0 - 1   -0.90576806 #> 5 synthetic outcome_1                0    0 - 1    0.05574247 #> 6 synthetic outcome_2                0    0 - 1   -0.04593864 #> 7 synthetic outcome_1                1    0 - 1    0.05574247 #> 8 synthetic outcome_2                1    0 - 1   -0.04593864

title: Nullify Active Edges — nullify
text: inference, often want work synthetic negative controls. One way define specify submodels full mediation analysis model. function defines submodels removing estimated edges according prespecified vector IDs. example, setting nulls = "T -> Y" remove direct effect sampling obtaining predictions full mediation analysis model \(hat{Y}\).

title: Nullify Active Edges — nullify
code: nullify(multimedia, nulls = NULL)

title: Nullify Active Edges — nullify
text: multimedia fitted object class multimedia estimates along paths mediation analysis DAG. nulls string specifying indices edges ignore. "T->Y", "T->M", "M->Y" match edges treatment outcome, treatment mediator, etc. Otherwise, vector indices specifying edges ignore.

title: Nullify Active Edges — nullify
text: multimedia version input multimedia model edges matching nulls removed. Enables sampling synthetic null controls.

title: Nullify Active Edges — nullify
code: # example with null data exper <- demo_joy() |>     mediation_data("PHQ", "treatment", starts_with("ASV")) fit <- multimedia(exper) |>     estimate(exper)  nullify(fit, "T->M") |>     estimate(exper) |>     indirect_overall() #>   outcome direct_setting            contrast indirect_effect #> 1     PHQ        Control Control - Treatment               0 #> 2     PHQ      Treatment Control - Treatment               0 nullify(fit, "T->Y") |>     estimate(exper) |>     direct_effect() #>   outcome indirect_setting            contrast direct_effect #> 1     PHQ          Control Control - Treatment             0 #> 2     PHQ        Treatment Control - Treatment             0  # example with another dataset exper <- demo_spline(tau = c(2, 1)) |>     mediation_data(starts_with("outcome"), "treatment", "mediator") fit <- multimedia(exper) |>     estimate(exper)  nullify(fit, "T->M") |>     estimate(exper) |>     indirect_overall() #>     outcome direct_setting contrast indirect_effect #> 1 outcome_1              0    0 - 1               0 #> 2 outcome_2              0    0 - 1               0 #> 3 outcome_1              1    0 - 1               0 #> 4 outcome_2              1    0 - 1               0 nullify(fit, "T->Y") |>     estimate(exper) |>     direct_effect() #>     outcome indirect_setting contrast direct_effect #> 1 outcome_1                0    0 - 1             0 #> 2 outcome_2                0    0 - 1             0 #> 3 outcome_1                1    0 - 1             0 #> 4 outcome_2                1    0 - 1             0

title: Parallelize Estimation across Responses — parallelize
code: mat <- data.frame(matrix(rnorm(100), 25, 4)) colnames(mat) <- c("y1", "y2", "x1", "x2") plm <- parallelize(lm) plm(y1 + y2 ~ x1 + x2, mat) #> $y1 #>  #> Call: #> f(formula = fmla, data = ..1) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)           x1           x2   #>     0.10108     -0.02537     -0.40630   #>  #>  #> $y2 #>  #> Call: #> f(formula = fmla, data = ..1) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)           x1           x2   #>    -0.11824      0.04479     -0.13584   #>  #>   prf <- parallelize(ranger::ranger) prf(mpg + hp ~ wt + disp + cyl, data = mtcars) #> $mpg #> Ranger result #>  #> Call: #>  f(fmla, ...)  #>  #> Type:                             Regression  #> Number of trees:                  500  #> Sample size:                      32  #> Number of independent variables:  3  #> Mtry:                             1  #> Target node size:                 5  #> Variable importance mode:         none  #> Splitrule:                        variance  #> OOB prediction error (MSE):       5.938088  #> R squared (OOB):                  0.8365249  #>  #> $hp #> Ranger result #>  #> Call: #>  f(fmla, ...)  #>  #> Type:                             Regression  #> Number of trees:                  500  #> Sample size:                      32  #> Number of independent variables:  3  #> Mtry:                             1  #> Target node size:                 5  #> Variable importance mode:         none  #> Splitrule:                        variance  #> OOB prediction error (MSE):       1962.015  #> R squared (OOB):                  0.5826269  #>

what: Predictions from a Multimedia Class — predict,multimedia-method
title: Predictions from a Multimedia Class — predict,multimedia-method
text: generalizes built-predict method multimedia class.  Given estimated multimedia object, function supports prediction along estimated DAG. first predicts hat[M] | T, X hat[Y] | hat[M], T, X. prediction step call prediction method within mediation outcome models make multimedia object called. passing new treatment, mediator, pretreatment data, can predict forward along DAG using inputs.

title: Predictions from a Multimedia Class — predict,multimedia-method
code: # S4 method for class 'multimedia' predict(object, profile = NULL, mediators = NULL, pretreatment = NULL, ...)

title: Predictions from a Multimedia Class — predict,multimedia-method
text: object object class multimedia containing estimated mediation outcome models whose mediation outcome predictions want obtain. profile object class treatment_profile containing treatment profile consider difference. Defaults profile unique treatment configurations observed original data, shared across mediators outcomes. mediators default, return outcome predictions using predicted mediators mediation model. Modify argument like directly control mediation inputs outcome model. Must data.frame whose columns named match mediators(object). pretreatment default, return mediation outcome model predictions using pretreatment variables used initially estimating models (like setting newdata = NULL usual predict). pass different pretreatment variables, provide data.frame whose columns match pretreatments originally trained mediation outcome models. ... placeholder agree predict base R. ever used.

title: Predictions from a Multimedia Class — predict,multimedia-method
text: list two elements: $mediators: data.frame containing predicted values mediators. row corresponds one row newdata, one row default treatment profile, newdata given. $outcomes: data.frame containing predicted values outcomes, given either () predicted values mediators (ii) provided values mediators. row corresponds one row newdata, one row default treatment profile, newdata given.

title: Predictions from a Multimedia Class — predict,multimedia-method
code: exper <- demo_spline(tau = c(2, 1)) |>     mediation_data(starts_with("outcome"), "treatment", "mediator") fit <- multimedia(exper, rf_model()) |>     estimate(exper) predict(fit) #> $mediators #> # A tibble: 2 × 1 #>   mediator #>      <dbl> #> 1    -1.43 #> 2     1.51 #>  #> $outcomes #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   outcome_1 outcome_2 #>       <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1    -0.756     0.758 #> 2     2.52      0.170 #>   # at new treatment configurations t1 <- data.frame(treatment = factor(rep(c(0, 1), each = 5))) profile <- setup_profile(fit, t_mediator = t1, t_outcome = t1) predict(fit, profile) #> $mediators #> # A tibble: 10 × 1 #>    mediator #>       <dbl> #>  1    -1.43 #>  2    -1.43 #>  3    -1.43 #>  4    -1.43 #>  5    -1.43 #>  6     1.51 #>  7     1.51 #>  8     1.51 #>  9     1.51 #> 10     1.51 #>  #> $outcomes #> # A tibble: 10 × 2 #>    outcome_1 outcome_2 #>        <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1    -0.756     0.758 #>  2    -0.756     0.758 #>  3    -0.756     0.758 #>  4    -0.756     0.758 #>  5    -0.756     0.758 #>  6     2.52      0.170 #>  7     2.52      0.170 #>  8     2.52      0.170 #>  9     2.52      0.170 #> 10     2.52      0.170 #>   # at new treatment and mediator configurations mediators <- data.frame(mediator = rnorm(10, 0, 1)) predict(fit, profile, mediators) #> $mediators #>      mediator #> 1   0.8392417 #> 2   0.1326461 #> 3  -0.9997034 #> 4   0.5717955 #> 5  -0.3069072 #> 6  -0.5303243 #> 7  -0.3217210 #> 8   0.3139278 #> 9   0.6225686 #> 10  0.3793470 #>  #> $outcomes #> # A tibble: 10 × 2 #>    outcome_1 outcome_2 #>        <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1     0.593   -0.310  #>  2     0.572   -0.0176 #>  3    -0.551    0.395  #>  4     0.594   -0.260  #>  5     0.447    0.0536 #>  6     2.38     0.874  #>  7     2.45     0.803  #>  8     2.59     0.507  #>  9     2.59     0.278  #> 10     2.59     0.391  #>

Even though can never know whether exists, can measure sensitivity conclusions existence/strength confounder. function, approach inducing (unallowable) correlation mediator outcome model residuals, simulate forward, see estimated overall indirect effect changes.

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Overall Indirect Effect — sensitivity

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Overall Indirect Effect — sensitivity
text: model multimedia object containing fitted models sensitivity analysis. Note since approach relies correlating simulated residual error, applicable models class lm_model(), glmnet_model() rf_model(). exper original mediation_data class object used fit model. observations resampled support bootstrap confidence interval construction sensitivity curve. confound_ix data.frame specifying mediator/outcome allowed correlated. two columns: 'mediator' 'outcome' specifying pairs mediators outcomes correlated. Defaults NULL, creates data.frame rows (enforcing independence mediators outcomes) rho_seq evaluate correlations Cor(e', e) mediation outcome model errors ranging along grid. Defaults NULL, internally sets sequence rho = (-0.9, -0.7 ..., 0.7, 0.9). n_bootstrap number bootstrap resamples used build confidence bands around sensitivity curves. Defaults 100. progress logical indicating whether show progress bar. ... Additional keyword arguments passed indirect_overall.

title: Sensitivity to User-Specified Perturbations — sensitivity_perturb
text: model multimedia object containing fitted models sensitivity analysis. Note since approach relies correlating simulated residual error, applicable models class lm_model(), glmnet_model() rf_model(). exper original mediation_data class object used fit model. observations resampled support bootstrap confidence interval construction sensitivity curve. perturb matrix towards original mediator-outcome covariance perturbed. Must dimension (n_mediators + n_outcomes) x (n_mediators + n_outcomes). nu_seq strength perturbation towards matrix perturb. n_bootstrap number bootstrap resamples used build confidence bands around sensitivity curves. Defaults 100. progress logical indicating whether show progress bar.

title: Sensitivity to User-Specified Perturbations — sensitivity_perturb
text: Specifically, defines new covariance matrix across mediators outcomes according diag(sigma^2_mediator, sigma^2_outcome) + nu * perturb. estimates sigma^2 taken residuals original mediation outcome models, perturb nu provided user.

title: Sensitivity to User-Specified Perturbations — sensitivity_perturb
code: xy_data <- demo_spline() exper <- mediation_data(     xy_data, starts_with("outcome"), "treatment", "mediator" ) model <- multimedia(     exper,     outcome_estimator = glmnet_model(lambda = 1e-2) ) |>     estimate(exper) rho_seq <- c(-0.2, 0.2) perturb <- matrix(     c(         0, 3, 0,         3, 0, 0,         0, 0, 0     ),     nrow = 3, byrow = TRUE ) sensitivity_perturb(model, exper, perturb, n_bootstrap = 2) #> # A tibble: 24 × 6 #> # Groups:   outcome, direct_setting, contrast [4] #>        nu outcome direct_setting contrast indirect_effect indirect_effect_stan…¹ #>     <dbl> <chr>   <fct>          <chr>              <dbl>                  <dbl> #>  1 -1 e-1 outcom… 0              0 - 1            -0.0891                0.0286  #>  2 -6 e-2 outcom… 0              0 - 1            -0.104                 0.00728 #>  3 -2 e-2 outcom… 0              0 - 1            -0.143                 0.00462 #>  4  2.e-2 outcom… 0              0 - 1            -0.203                 0.00137 #>  5  6 e-2 outcom… 0              0 - 1            -0.237                 0.00594 #>  6  1 e-1 outcom… 0              0 - 1            -0.300                 0.00830 #>  7 -1 e-1 outcom… 1              0 - 1            -0.0891                0.0286  #>  8 -6 e-2 outcom… 1              0 - 1            -0.104                 0.00728 #>  9 -2 e-2 outcom… 1              0 - 1            -0.143                 0.00462 #> 10  2.e-2 outcom… 1              0 - 1            -0.203                 0.00137 #> # ℹ 14 more rows #> # ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​indirect_effect_standard_error
